Fragment: Borachio, thou art read In Nature and her large Philosophie.
But where that fauour of his Nature is Not full and free;
you see a man becomes A foole, as little-knowing as a beast.
Then if Death casts vp Our totall summe of ioy and happinesse;
Let me haue all my sences feasted in Th'abundant fulnesse of delight at once,
with a sweet insensible increase Of pleasing surfet melt into my dust.
to die so soon? and if our time runnes home vnto the length Of Nature,
pleasure onely flowes Vpon the streame of riches.
Wealth is Lord Of all felicitie.
Had not my Body spredde it selfe Into posteritie; perhaps I should Desire no more increase of substance, then Would hold proportion with mine owne dimentions.
those accidents, the least whereof May robbe him of an ages husbandry?
And for my children; they are as neere to me, As branches to the tree whereon they grow; And may as numerously be multiplied.
from my substance they [my children] receiue the sap, Whereby they liue and flowrish.
How deiectedly The baser Spirit of our present time Hath cast it selfe below the ancient worth Of our forefathers!
the scorne of their [the troops' leaders] discourse, Turnes smiling backe vpon your backewardnesse.
To curbe me, hee denyes me maintenance To put me in the habite of my ranque.
Vnbinde me from that strong necessitie,
I'de disinherite my posteritie To purchase honour.
T'is [honour] an interest I prize aboue the principall of wealth.
my substance shall vnlocke It selfe to serue you.
the pregnant wit of Man, might make The happy absence of this Charlemont, A subiect for commodious prouidence.
And my heart [bounded by your resolution] to thee.
Here are my Sonnes, There's my eternitie. My life in them;
their [my sons] succession shall for euer liue.
And in my reason dwels the prouidence, To adde to life as much of happinesse.
Let all men lose, so I increase my gaine, I haue no feeling of anothers paine.
let this current of my teares, Diuert thy inclination from the warre.
The weakest sigh you breath, hath power to turne My strongest purpose;
your [the father's] softest teare To melt my resolution to as soft Obedience.
But my affection to the warre, Is as heriditary as my bloud To eu'ry life of all my ancestry.
Shall I serue For nothing but a vaine Parenthesis, I'th'honour'd story of your Familie?
hang but like an emptie Scutcheon, Betweene the trophee's of my predecessours. And the rich Armes of my posteritie?
Onely Charlemont Must be reputed that same heartlesse thing, That Cowards will be bold to play vpon.
ha'you wash'd your eyes wi'teares this morning?
Your tendernesse disswades him. What to the Father of a Gentleman, Should be more tender then the maintenance And the increase of honour to his house?
eu'n the time, place, manner of our deathes, Doe follow Fate with that necessitie That makes vs sure to dye.
Accomplements are more for ornament Than vse.
this accomplement Is like an elegant and mouing speech, Compos'd of many sweete perswasiue points, Which second one onother, with a fluent Increase, and confirmation of their force,
Reseruing still the best vntill the last, To crowne the strong impulsion of the rest With a full conquest of the hearers sense:

you (deare Mistresse) being the last and best That speakes my farewell; like th'imperious cloze Of a most sweete Oration, wholy haue Possess'd my liking, and shall euer liue Within the soule of my true memory.
T'was [a kiss] not meant to separate A paire of Louers; but to be the seale Of Loue;
importing by the ioyning of Our mutuall and incorporated breathes, That we should breath but one contracted life.
I salute you both with the spirit of copulation,
when a certaine great man went to th'warre, The louely face of heau'n was masqu'd with sorrow,
[when a certaine great man went to th'warre] The sighing windes did moue the breast of earth,

The heauie cloudes hung downe their mourning heads, And wept sad showers the day that hee [the great man] went hence [to war[, As if that day presag'd some ill successe, That fatallie should kill his happinesse;
Me thinkes my eyes (Sweet Heau'n forbid) are like those weeping cloudes, And as their showers presag'd so doe my teares, Some sad euent will follow my sad feares.
what is't but a Rape to force a wench to marry,
May all my feares hurt me no more then this [a kiss].
A lustie bloud!
by the lip of Loue
Her power to speake is perish'd in her teares.
this [the comliments] worshipping kinde of entertainment, is a superstitious vanitie;
I embrace your disposition
In the behauiour of his noble daughter Castabella a man may read her worth and your instruction.
You haue giuen me her picture in small [through language]
Shee's like your Dyamond
Prophane not your lippes with the foulnesse of that sinne [swearing]
my praise came short of her worth. Shee exceedes a Iewell. This is but onely for ornament; Shee both for ornament and vse.
Yet vnprofitably kept without vse. Shee deserues a worthy Husband, Sir.
thy gratuitie and my promises were both but words; and both like words shall vanish into ayre.

compare's profession with his life; They so directly contradict themselues, As if the end of his instructions were But to diuert the world from sinne, that hee More easily might ingrosse it to himselfe.
His absence the foundation of my plot.
To draw his inclination out o'th'way.
T'has left the passage of our practise free.
That [profitable policie] it would make the soule of honestie Ambitious to turne villaine.
No man shall rob thee of the honour.
The gray eie'd Morning makes the fairest day.
[love you] With all my hart.
Then with all my hart, Ile giue you a Iewell to hang in your eare, —Harke yee—I can neuer loue you.
Call you this [doesn't love him] a Iewell to hang in mine eare?
T'is [doesn't love him] no light fauour, for Ile be sworne it comes somewhat heauily to mee.
Her soft excuses sauour'd at the first (Me thought) but of a modest innocence Of bloud; whose vnmoou'd streame was neuer drawne Into the current of affection.
Her modest blush fell to a pale dislike,
now so strong a hand seekes to diuide [the love contract]:
I know your heart cannot prophane The holinesse you make profession of;
with a purpose so contracted to that absence, that you see hee purchases your separation with the hazard of his bloud and life;
T'is rather hate that doth diuision moue;
Loue still desires the presence of his Loue. —Verily, hee is not of the Familie of Loue.
gentle loue and noble courage are So neare allyed; that one begets another:
Loue is Sister, and Courage is the Brother.
Could I affect him better then before, His Souldiers heart would make me loue him more.
you mistake the way into a woman, The passage lyes not through her reason, but her bloud.
Nature the louing mother of vs all, Brought forth a woman for her owne reliefe, By generation to reuiue her age.
Preferr'st th' affection of an absent Loue, Before the sweet possession of a man; The barren minde before the fruitfull body;
(vnlesse Our children can be gotten by conceit) Must from the body come.
If Reason were Our counsellour, wee would neglect the worke Of generation, for the prodigall Expence it drawes vs to of that which is The wealth of life.
Wise Nature (therefore) hath Reseru'd for an inducement to our sence, Our greatest pleasure in that greatest worke.
An absent man Whose bloud once spent i'th'warre;
he'l [soldier] come home, sicke, lame and impotent; And wed thee to a torment; like the paine Of Tantalus, continuing thy desire, With fruitlesse presentation of the thing It loues;
Yet if shee were my very flesh and bloud, I could aduise no better for good.
Thy ioyfull husband thus salutes Thy cheeke.
your puritie Professes a diuine contempt o'th'world;
I may be of A nature so vnpleasing to your minde; Perhaps you'l curse the fatall houre wherein You rashly marryed me.
O my presaging teares! This sad euent hath follow'd my sad feares.
his Tongue is an vnsanctified member.
your grauitie becomes your perish'd soule, as hoary mouldinesse does rotten fruit.
by my Soule Ile plague thee for this rudenesse.
The nearer the Church; the further from God.
may his abilitie die in his appetite;
May his appetite moue thy desire to another man: so hee shall helpe to make himselfe Cuckold.

Let the Chambers be matted, the hinges oyl'd, the curtaine rings silenced, and the chamber-maid hold her peace at his owne request, that he may sleepe the quietlier. And in that sleepe let him be soundly cuckolded.
the Law will take no hold of her, because he wink'd at it.
if they bid thee not welcome, they are very Loggerheads.
If your Logger heads will not, your Hoggesheads shall Madame, if I get into the Buttry.
T'is out of season to be heauily disposed.
We should be all wound vp into the key of Mirth.
Let the Instruments of warre congratulate his memorie
My soule fore-tels hee brings the newes will make our Musicke full.
O my spirit, it does disswade my tongue to question him, as if it knew his answere would displease.
Plants all th' Artillerie against the Towne, Whose thunder and lightning made our bulwarkes shake; And threatned in that terrible report, The storme wherewith they meant to second it.
his pollicie Let goe the sluices, and Of the whole bodie of their troupe, trip'd vp the heeles
expos'd The force of all their spirits, (like the last Expiring gaspe of a strong harted man) Vpon the hazard of one charge
Among the slaughter'd bodies of their men, Which the full-stomack'd Sea had cast vpon The sands,
Hee lay in's Armour; as if that had beene His Coffine,
the weeping Sea (like one Whose milder temper doth lament the death Of him whom in his rage he slew)
[the weeping sea] runnes vp The Shoare; embraces him; kisses his cheeke, Goes backe againe and forces vp the Sandes To burie him; and eu'rie time it parts, Sheds teares vpon him;
till at last (as if It [the sea] could no longer endure to see the man Whom it had slaine, yet loath to leaue him;) with A kinde of vnresolu'd vnwilling pace,
Winding her [the sea] waues one in another, like A man that foldes his armes, or wrings his hands For griefe;
ebb'd from the body and descends: As if it [sea] would sinke downe into the earth, And hide it selfe for shame of such a deede.
Your feare hath told you that whereof my griefe Was loath to be the messenger.
Torment me not with witnesses [the scarf] of that [his son's death], Which I desire, not to beleeue;
Thou art a Scrichowle; and dost come i'night To be the cursed messenger of death.
Your loue to vexe my heart with that I hate?
this vncertaine state of mortall man! - it is th'ineuitable fate Of all things vnderneath the Moone.
With all my heart [he'll give counsel]
Your health [drink/blessing] will make me sicke sir.
My body is as weake as water,
the beere has sent all the malt vp into your braine, and left nothing but the water in your body.
Let them drinke healthes, & drowne their braines i'the floud;
they shall be pledg'd in bloud.
Fortune, I honour thee.
What ha'you drunke your selues mad you knaues.
I will sindge the goose [your brother, Monteferrers] by this torch.
Who can but strike, wants wisedome to maintaine: Hee that strikes safe and sure, has heart and braine.
O Loue! thou chast affection of the Soule, Without th'adultrate mixture of the bloud;
That vertue [love] which to goodnesse addeth good: The minion of heauens heart.
Then I confesse thy anger's not vniust. I was thy [heaven's] riuall [over Charlemont's love]
Yet to be diuorc'd From loue, has beene a punishment enough. (Sweete heauen) without being marryed vnto hate,
Yet since thy pleasure hath inflicted it, If not my heart, my dutie shall submit.
your sicknesse will Distaste th'expected sweetnesse o'the night.
Pleasure be your bed-fellow.
Why sure their Generation was asleepe, When shee begot those Dormice; that shee made Them vp so weakely and imperfectly.
When my affection euen with their cold blouds (As snow rub'd through an actiue hand, does make The flesh to burne)
[When my affection euen with their cold blouds] by agitation is Inflam'd, I could vnbrace, and entertaine The ayre to coole it.
That but mitigates The heate; rather imbrace and entertaine A younger brother; he can quench the fire.
A lusty bloud! has both the presence and the spirit of a man.
Has set my bloud o'boyling i'my veynes
now (like water pour'd vpon the ground,  that mixes it selfe with eu'ry moysture it meetes) I could claspe with any man.
Lust is a Spirit, which whosoe'er doth raise, The next man that encounters boldly, layes.
My soule's opprest with griefe. T'lies heauie at my heart,
Eternall darkenesse damne you [the servants];
I thinke that Dogge that howl'd the newes of griefe, that fatall Scrichowle vsherd on this mischiefs.
Dead be your tongues.
Drop out mine eye-bals, and let enuious Fortune play at tennis with'em.
Malicious Nature! hadst thou borne me blinde; th'adst yet been something fauourable to me.
heauen! hast shut thine eye to winke at murther; or hast put this sable garment on, to mourne at's death?
Not one poore sparke in the whole spatious skye, of all that endlesse number would vouchsafe to shine?
You [stars] vize-royes to the King of nature!
[king of nature] whose constellations gouerne mortall births;

where is that fatall Planet rul'd at his Natiuitie? That might ha'pleas'd to light him out, as well into th'world; vnlesse it be asham'd T'haue beene the instrument of such a good mans cursed destinie.
Passions transports you.
Doe you thinke that Nature has no feeling?
Feeling? Yes. But has she [nature] purpos'd any thing for nothing?
had hee beene taken from mee like a piece o'dead flesh, I should neither ha' felt it, nor grieued for't.
the true freshnesse of a sanguine red;  for all the fogge of this blacke murdrous night has mix'd with it [blood]
hee might ha' liu'd till doomesday,
He [brother] was a man of such a natiue goodnesse; as if Regeneration had beene giuen him in his mothers wombe.
So deerely pittifull, that e're the poore could aske his charity with dry eyes, hee gaue' em reliefe wi'teares
For wisedom's sake let reason fortifie this weakenesse.
Foolish Nature will haue her course in spight o'wisedome.
All these wordes were but a great winde, and now this showre of teares has layd it, I am calme againe.
The griefe that melts to teares, by itselfe is spent,
Here's a sweete Comedie. T'begins with O dolentis, and concludes with ha, ha, he.
O my eccho! I could stand reuerberating this sweete musicall ayre of ioy, till I had perish'd my sound lungs with violent laughter.
Lonely Night-Rauen! th'ast seaz'd a carkasse.
I knock'd out's braines with this faire Rubie. And had another stone iust of this forme and bignesse ready: that I laid i'the broken skull vpo'the ground for's pillow;
Vpon this ground Ile build my Manour-house; And this [the skull] shall be the chiefest corner stone.
T'has crown'd the most iudicious murder, that The braine of man was e'er deliuer'd of.
my report that Charlemont was dead, Though false; yet couer'd with a masque of truth.
T'was easie to set drunkards by the eares:
Then darkenesse did Protect the execution of the worke,
That power of rule Philosophers ascribe To him they call the supreame of the Starres; Making their influences gouernours Of Sublunarie Creatures; when their selues Are senselesse of their operations.
the angry exhalation shut within a prison of contrary qualitie, striues to be free; and with the violent eruption through the grossenesse of that cloud; makes this noyse we heare [thunder]
T'is a braue noyse. And mee thinkes graces our accomplishid proiect, as a peale of Ordnance does a triumph.
It [the thunder] speakes encouragement.
Now Nature showes thee how it sauour'd our performance;
propitious Nature winck'd at our proceedings; now it doth expresse, how that forbearance fauour'd our successe.
That Nature (since herselfe decay doth hate) Should fauour those that strengthen their estate.
Now farewell blacke night; Thou beauteous Mistresse of a murderer:
To honour thee [night], that hast accomplish'd all; Ile weare thy colours at his funerall.
Thy Mistresse is of a liuely attractiue bloud,
A poore spirit is poorer then a poore purse.
Hot diet and soft ease makes em (like waxe alwaies kept warme) more easie to take impression.
That [the blush] showes th'art full o'lustie bloud

I doe not like these flegmaticke, smooth-skinn'd, soft-flesh'd fellowes. They are like candied Suckets, when they begin to perish; which I would alwayes emptie my Closet off, and giue'em my chamber-maid.
if thou doest not lose her with faint-heartednesse.
a Lady is a great thing, I cannot compasse her.
Am I so great I cannot be compassed? Claspe my wast and try.
I could finde i'my heart
Faint-hearted foole!
I thinke thou wert begotten betweene the North-pole, and the congeal'd passage.
Now like an ambitious Coward that betrayes himselfe with fearefull delay: you must suffer for the treason you neuer committed.
you very valiant, for you met [kissed] mee at full Cariere.
A word or two, Madame? that you doe for mee, will not be contain'd in lesse then the compasse of two sheetes.
To dance the beginning of the world after the English manner.
There's one at the doore has beaten opportunitie away from vs.
Has shooke mee almost into a dead palsie.
My memory is almost frighted from mee.
my feete were base and cowardly feete, they stuncke for feare.
How soeuer it sauours [of distraction], I am sure it smels like a lye.
Why t'isa musique Souldier. Heauen and earth are now in consort, when the Thunder and the Canon play one to another.
Our boyling phantasies Like troubled waters falsifie the shapes Of things retain'd in them; and make' em seeme Confounded, when they are distinguish'd,
My actions daily conuersant with warre; (The argument of bloud and death)
Incorporate; as if his body were The owner of that bloud, the subiect of That death;
the Diuel's damme has broke her husbands head:
my doubtfull heart was slow To credit that which I did feare to know.
SEt downe the Body. Pay earth what shee lent.
shee [earth] shall beare a liuing monument, To let succeeding ages truely know That shee is satisfied, what hee did owe:
And with his Body, place that memorie Of noble Charlemont
The Father Held open warre with Sinne;
the Sonne [held open war] with bloud:
HEre lye the Ashes of that earth and fire; whose heat and fruit, did feede and warme the poore.
they [the poor] (as if they would in sighes expire, and into teares dissolue) his death deplore.
For ag'd in vertue with a youthfull eye,
O might that fire reuiue the ashes of This Phenix! yet the wonder would not be So great as he was good;
His life's example was so true A practique of Religion's Theorie, That her Diuinitie seem'd rather the Description then th'instruction of his life.
on These two Herculean pillars, where their armes Are plac'd; there may be writ, Non vltra.
faire accomplements make foule Deedes gratious.
I'ue buryed vnder these two marble stones Thy liuing hopes;
be not displeas'd, if on The altar of his Tombe, I sacrifice My teares. They are the iewels of my loue Dissolued into griefe
and fall [the tears] vpon His blasted Spring; as Aprill dewe, vpon A sweet young blossome shak'd before the time.
How can the Marchant, or The Marriner absent whole yeares (from wiues Experienc'd in the satisfaction of Desire) promise themselues to finde their sheetes Vnspotted with adultery, at their Returne?
was thy bloud Increas'd to such a pleurisie of lust, That of necessitie, there must a veyne Be open'd; though by one that had no skill To doe't?
your iniur'd patience may behold The signes of his lamented memorie.
all mens woes are buried i' their graues
In mine [grave] my miseries are borne.
I pr'ithee sorrow leaue a little roome, In my confounded and tormented mind; For vnderstanding to deliberate The cause or author of this accident.
Whereof the lightest [wrong], is more heauie then The strongest patience can endure to beare.
Gen'rall honestie possess'd me.
th'art the base corruption of my bloud; And like a Tetter growes't vnto my flesh.
The want of money makes a free spirit more mad then the possession does an Vsurer.
For want is like the Racque; it drawes a man to endanger himselfe to the gallowes rather then endure it.
compose me. I dissolue.
I tooke you for a Spirit; and Ile coniure you before I ha'done.
Ile turne Coniurer. Diuell! within this Circle, in the midst of all thy force and malice I coniure thee doe thy worst.
Thou [Charlemont] gau'st mee my life and that's somewhat of a purer earth then gold as fine as it is.
T'is no courtesie I doe thee but thankefulnesse. I owe thee it and Ile pay it.

may the sins o'the poore people be so few, that you sha'not be able to spare so much out o'your gettings, as will pay for the hyre of a lame staru'd hackney to ride to an execution, But goe a foote to the gallowes, and be hang'd.
If this curse might come to passe, the world would say, Blessed be he that curseth.

When our afflictions doe exceede our crimes? Then they doe rather teach the barb'rous world Examples that extend her cruelties Beyond their owne dimentions; and instruct Our actions to be more, more barbarous.
O my afflicted soule! How torment swels Thy apprehension with prophane conceipt, Against the sacred iustice of my God?
We neuer measure our Conditions but with Men aboue vs in Estate. So while our Spirits labour to Be higher then our fortunes they are more base.
The penurie of a prison is like a soft consumption. T'will humble the pride o' your mortalitie; and arme your soule in compleate patience to endure the waight of affliction without feeling it.
Hast no musicke in thee? Th'hast trebles and bases enough. Treble iniurie; and base vsage. But trebles and bases make poore musick without meanes.
I haue a heart aboue the reach Of thy most violent maliciousnesse.
A fortitude in scorne of thy contempt; (Since Fate is pleas'd to haue me suffer it) That can beare more then thou hast power t'inflict.
I'ue lost a Signiorie, That was confin'd within a piece of earth; A Wart vpon the body of the world.
But now I am an Emp'rour of a world. This little world of Man. My passions are My Subiects; and I can command them laugh; Whilst thou doest tickle'em to death with miserie.
Yet hee lookes not for thankes. For he does it vnder hand;
Out o' great heart you'l refus't [the money] now;
Since I must submit my selfe to Fate; I neuer will neglect the offer of one benefit; but entertaine them as her fauours; and th'inductions to some end of better fortune.
Since by your greatnesse, you Are nearer heau'n in place; be nearer it In goodnesse.
Rich men should transcend the poore, As clouds the earth; rais'd by the comfort of The Sunne, to water dry and barren grounds.
Let nature, which in Sauages, in beasts, Can stirre to pittie, tell you that hee is Your kinsman;
Nephew, had not his open freedome made My disposition knowne; I would ha'borne The course and inclination of my loue According to the motion of the Sunne, Inuisibly inioyed and vnderstood.
I will supply your Fathers vacant place, To guide your greene improuidence of youth; And make you ripe for your inheritance.
I embrance your gen'rous promises.
For with the hand of our whole family We enterchange th'indenture of our Loues.
A gen'rall weakenesse did surprise my health The very day I married Castabella. As if my sicknesse were a punishment, That did arrest me for some iniurie I then committed.
The eternall bond of our concluded loue.
their branches spreading and winding one within another as if they did embrace.

A poppring Peare-tree growing vpon the banke of a Riuer; seeming continually to looke downewards into the water, as if it were enamour'd of it; and euer as the fruit ripens, lets it fall for loue (as it were) into her lap.

Which the wanton Streame, like a Strumpet, no sooner receiues, but she carries it away, and bestowes it vpon some other creature she maintaines: still seeming to play and dally vnder the Poppring, so long, that it has almost wash'd away the earth from the roote;
now the poore Tree stands as if it were readie to fall and perish by that whereon it spent all the substance it had.
Morall for you that loue those wanton running waters.
This is a sweet straine, thou finger'st it beastly.
My Lady and Sebastian the Fall and the Tyre, and I the Shadow.
I perceiue the puritie of my conuersation is vs'd but for a propertie to couer the vncleanenesse of their purposes.
The very contemplation o' the thing, makes the spirit of the flesh begin to wriggle in my bloud.
The fairenesse o' the euening inuites me into the ayre;
With all my heart Sir [I agree]
The flesh is humble till the Spirit moue it; But when t'is rais'd it will command aboue it.
That fellowes life, Borachio, Like a superfluous Letter in the Law, Endangers our assurance.
For what effect and end I haue engag'd My selfe in all this bloud?
To leaue a state To the succession of my proper bloud.
How fit a place for contemplation is this dead of night, among the dwellings of the dead.
he was lesse rich and lesse contented, then in this poore piece of earth, lower and lesser then a Cottage.
Now that his body fauours of corruption; Hee enioyes a sweeter rest then e'er hee did amongst the sweetest pleasures of this life.
O that Man, with so much labour should aspire to wordly height; when in the humble earth, the world's condition's at the best!
scorne inferiour men; since to be lower then a worme, is to be higher then a King!
I come of a generation both by Father and Mother, that were all as fruitfull as Costard-mongers wiues.
a Timpanie is the greatest danger can be fear'd. Their fruitfulnesse turnes but to a certaine kind of flegmatique windie disease.
My bodie is not euery day drawne dry
your want of vse should rather make your body like a Well, the lesser t'is drawne, the sooner it growes dry.
vnder the close Curtaines of the night;
this conuccation-house of dead mens sculles
Death's head! deceiu'st my hold? Such is the trust to all mortalitic
The smallest ornament of thy sweet forme (that abstract of all pleasure) can command the sences into passion;
I loue thee with the freedome of my reason.
My conscience suffers vnder't [the wrong]; and I would disburthen it by satisfaction.
Are y'a diuell or a man?
such a man, as can returne thy entertainment with as prodigall a body, as the couetous desire of woman euer was delighted with.
that besides the full performance of thy empty Husbands dutie;
For the appetite that steales her pleasure; drawes the forces of the body to an vnited strength
Would it not grieue thee, that a Stranger to thy bloud, should lay the first foundation of his house vpon the ruines of thy family?
the heire of him that was my Fathers enemie, raise his eternall monument vpon our ruines; ere the greatest pleasure or the greatest profit, euer tempt me to continue it by incest.
Incest? Tush. These distances affinitie obserues; are articles of bondage cast vpon our freedomes by our owne subiections.
if you argue meerely out of Nature; doe you not degenerate from that; and are you not vnworthie the prerogatiue of Natures Maister-piece,
the horrour of the argument confounds my vnderstanding.
quench it [your lust] on their prostituted flesh, whose trade of sinne can please desire with more delight, and lesse offence
The poyson of your breath; euaporated from so foule a soule; infects the ayre more then the dampes that rise from bodies but halfe rotten in their graues.
Kisse me, I warrant thee my breath is sweet.

O patient Heau'n! Why doest thou not expresse thy wrath in thunderbolts; to teare the frame of man in pieces?
How can earth endure the burthen of this wickednesse without an earthquake?
Or the angry face of Heau'n be not enflam'd with lighning.
Coniure vp the Diuell and his Dam; Crie to the graues; the dead can heare thee; inuocate their helpe.
O would this graue might open, and my body were bound to the dead carkasse of a man for euer, e're it entertaine the lust of this detested villaine.
Tereas-like, thus I will force my passage to—
with the hand of Charlemont, I thus redeeme you from the arme of lust.
Now sweet Death, I'le bid thee welcome.
I'le cast my selfe into the armes of apprehension, that the law may make this worthie worke, the crowne of all my actions being the best and last
the hand of Heau'n directed thy defence.
My soule is heauie.
These [graves?] are the pillowes whereon men sleepe best. They lie downe with either of them a Death's head for a pillow.
Now puritie defend me from the sinne of Sodom. —This is a creature of the  masculine gender.—Verily the Man is blasted.
Why doest thou stare vpon me? Thou art not the scull of him I murder'd.

and [sky, the bawde] draw the curtaines of the clouds betweene those lights and me about this bed of earth, when that same Stumpet Murder & my selfe committed sin together. Then she  could leaue vs i' the darke, till the close deed was done:

(like a Leacher emptied of his lust) desire to burie my face vnder my eye-browes, and would steale from my shame vnseene; she meetes me i'th face with all her light corrupted eyes, to challenge payment
Yet the count'nance of a bloudlesse worme might ha' the courage now to turne my bloud to water.
The trembling motion of an Aspen leafe, would make me like the shadow of that leafe he shaking vnder't.
I could now commit a murder', were it but to drinke the fresh warme bloud of him I murder'd, to supply the want and weakenesse o'mine owne; t'is growne so colde and flegmaticke.
Mountaines o'erwhelme mee,
O were my body circumuolu'd within that cloude; that when the thunder teares his passage open, it might scatter me to nothing in the ayre!
Black Beelzebub, and all his hell-hounds come to apprehend me?
The Ghoast (great Pluto) was a foole; vnfit to be imployed in any serious businesse for the state of hell.
could not he ha' suffer'd me to raise the mountaine o' my sinnes with one as damnable as all the rest; and then ha' tumbled me to ruine?
A Ghoast? where my Lord?—I smell a Foxe [deception]
My braines begin to put themselues in order.
I will search the Center but I'le finde the murderer.
Sure there is some other happinesse within the freedome of the conscience, then my knowledge e'er attain'd too.
what Fate has cast you thus Vnhappily vpon this accident?
she's as cleare as Chastitie.
As her owne chastitie. The time; the place; All circumstances argue that vncleare.
Yet were it not my Sonnes bed she abus'd; My land should flie but both should be excus'd.
But iealousie is such a torment, that I am afraid to entertaine it. Yet The more I shunne by circumstance to meete Directly with it, the more ground I finde To circumuent my apprehension.

her owne bloud, corrupted, will Betray her to temptation.

My strange affection to this Man!—T'is like that naturall sympathie which e'en among the sencelesse creatures of the earth, commands a mutuall inclination and consent:
I think none of 'em [mistresses] are faithfull, but otherwise as many as cleane Shirts.
The loue of a woman is like a Mushrom; it growes in one night, and will serue somwhat pleasingly, next morning to breakfast: but afterwards waxes fulsome and vnwholesome.
a woman's loue lasts as long as Winter fruit.
[a woman's loue lasts as long as Winter fruit.] T'is true. Till new come in. By my experience no longer.
Some bodie's doing has vndone vs; and we are like pay dearely for't.
Wil't not be a chargeable reckoning, thinke you; when heere are halfe a dozen fellowes comming to call vs to account, with eu'rie man a seuerall bill in his hand, that wee are not able to discharge.
I will make my passage through thy bloud.
my Sebastian! Husband! Neither can spake; yet both report my shame.
Is this the sauing of my Honour, when their bloud runnes out in riuers; and my lust the fountaine whence it flowes?
But what can teares doe good; when I weepe onely water, they weepe bloud?
But could I make an Ocean with my teares; that on the floud this broken vessell of my body, laden heauie with light lust might suffer shipwrack, and so drowne my shame: then weeping were to purpose;
The Sea wants water enough to wash away the foulenesse of my name.
in their wounds, I feele my honour wounded to the death.
to make th'eexample moue more forceably to vertue; thus, I seale it [my life] with a death as full of horrour as my life of sinne.

Behold thou ignorant Astronomer, Whose wandring speculation seekes among The planets for mens fortunes!
with amazement, [Astonomer] Behold thine errour and be planet strucke.
These [coins] are the Starres whose operations make The fortunes and the destinies of men.

Yond' lesser eyes of Heau'n, (like Subiects rais'd Into their loftie houses, when their Prince Rides vnderneath th'ambition of their loues) Are mounted onely to behold the face, Of your more rich imperious eminence, With vnpreuented sight.
Vnmaske faire Queene; (Vnpurses the gold.)
These [coins] are the Starres the Ministers of Fate; And Mans high wisedome the superiour power, To which their forces are subordinate.
while the simple honest worshipper Of a phantastique prouidence groanes vnder The burthen of neglected miserie; My reall wisedome has rais'd vp a State, That shall eternize my posteritie.
The cries of Mandrakes neuer touch'd the eare, with more sad horrour then that voice does mine.

Doctor! Behold two Patients, in whose cure thy skill may purchase an eternall fame.
let thy practise and their [the herbs] soueraigne vse raise thee to wealth and honour.

His gasping sighes are like the falling noise of some great building when the ground-worke breakes.
On these [sons] two pillars stood the stately frame, and architecture of my loftie house. An Earthquake shakes'em. The foundation shrinkes.
Deere Nature! in whose honour I haue rais'd a worke of glory to posteritie; O burie not the pride of that great action, vnder the fall and ruine of it selfe.
Take this gold; extract the Spirit of it, and inspire new life into their bodies.
there expires the date of my posteritie!
Can Nature be so simple or malicious to destroy the reputation of her proper memorie?
Nature thou art a Traytour to my soule. Thou hast abus'd my trust.
I will complaine to a superiour Court, to right my wrong I'le proue thee [Nature] a forger of false assurances. In yond' Starre chamber thou shalt answere it.

That worthie attribute of Gentrie, which Your habite drawes from ignorant respect; Your name deserues not: nor your selfe the name Of woman, Since you are the poyson that Infects the honour of all womanhood.
But vnder colour to professe the Sale Of Tyres and toyes for Gentlewomens pride; You draw a frequentation of mens wiues To your licentious house;
Since from the Spring of lust which you preseru'd,And nourish'd; ranne th' effusion of that bloud: Your punishment shall come as neare to death As life can beare it.

Since my thrift was more iudicious then your Grandsires; why, I would faine know why your Lordship liues to make a second generation from your Father and the whole frie of my posteritie extinguish'd in a moment.
Let Charitie forbeare To vexe the spirit of a dying Man.
A chearefull eye vpon the face of Death Is the true court'nance of a noble minde.
is't not enough that hee vniustly hath conspir'd with Fate, to cut off my posteritie for him to be the heire to my possessions;

Thus like a warlike Nauie on the Sea, Bound for the conquest of some wealthie land, Pass'd through the stormic troubles of this life, And now arriu'd vpon the armed coast; In expectation of the victorie, Whose honour lies beyond this exigent; Through mortall danger with an actiue spirit, Thus I aspire to vndergoe my death.
Our liues cut off, In our young prime of yeares; are like greene hearbs, Wherewith we strow the hearses of our friends.
For as their vertue gather'd when th'are greene, Before they wither or corrupt, is best;
So we in vertue are the best for Death, While yet we haue not liu'd to such an age, That the encreasing canker of our sinnes, Hath spread too farre vpon vs.
yet in me the resolution wants To die with that assurance as he does. The cause of that, in his Anatomie I would finde out.

Come thou [water] cleare embleme of coole temperance.
Be thou [water] my witnesse, that I vse no art To force my courage; nor haue neede of helpes, To raise my Spirits like those weaker men;
[weak men] Who mixe their bloud with wine, and out of that Adulterate coniunction doe beget A bastard valour.
Natiue courage, thankes. Thou lead'st me soberly to vndertake This great hard worke of magnanimitie.
at the reflexion of thy courage my cold fearefull bloud takes fire, and I begin to emulate thy death.
